abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, and sustainability is rated as likely. Overall
            performances of the World Bank and the Borrower are judged
            as satisfactory. Lessons learned that may help with
            continued implementation of the Coal Sector Reform or
            implementation of similar sectoral reforms in Poland or
            other countries are as follows: The Government's
            comprehensive approach to coal sector reform has been
            generally successful and should be maintained. The Program
            needs to be adjusted to changing market conditions, to
            ensure objectives, and not just the targets, of the reforms
            achieved. A new plan for further capacity and employment
            reduction should be developed during the final year of the
            present Program. It appears to be very difficult to continue
            employment restructuring on a solely voluntary basis.
            Financial viability is possible but reforms need to continue
            for this to be maintained. Privatization will be difficult
            unless further reforms take place, but should be a priority
            as it is required for real competition. Furthermore, the
            earlier that privatization is accomplished, the sooner the
            government will be able to transfer the price risk to
            private owners and operators and protect itself and the
            taxpayer from the risk of further subsidies. The extensive
            dialogue between the Government and the trade unions was
            important for the success of the Program. This type of
            dialogue will also be key in designing the industry's
            privatization and employment restructuring.
